Identification.LongTitle: An Act for the Recognition of Victims Rights

ReaderNote.Note: [Enacted by section 2 of chapter 13 of the Statutes of Canada, 2015, in force July 23, 2015.]

Provision.Text: Whereas crime has a harmful impact on victims and on society;
Whereas victims of crime and their families deserve to be treated with courtesy, compassion and respect, including respect for their dignity;
Whereas it is important that victims’ rights be considered throughout the criminal justice system;
Whereas victims of crime have rights that are guaranteed by the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms;
Whereas consideration of the rights of victims of crime is in the interest of the proper administration of justice;
Whereas the federal, provincial and territorial governments share responsibility for criminal justice;

Whereas, in 1988, the federal, provincial and territorial governments endorsed the Canadian Statement of Basic Principles of Justice for Victims of Crime and, in 2003, the Canadian Statement of Basic Principles of Justice for Victims of Crime, 2003;
Now, therefore, Her Majesty, by and with the advice and consent of the Senate and House of Commons of Canada, enacts as follows:

Section.Text: This Act may be cited as the Canadian Victims Bill of Rights.
The following definitions apply in this Act.

Definition.Text: offence means an offence under the Criminal Code, the Youth Criminal Justice Act or the Crimes Against Humanity and War Crimes Act, a designated substance offence as defined in subsection 2(1) of the Controlled Drugs and Substances Act or an offence under section 91 or Part 3 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act.
victim means an individual who has suffered physical or emotional harm, property damage or economic loss as the result of the commission or alleged commission of an offence.

Section.Text: Any of the following individuals may exercise a victim’s rights under this Act if the victim is dead or incapable of acting on their own behalf:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the victim’s spouse or the individual who was at the time of the victim’s death their spouse;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the individual who is or was at the time of the victim’s death, cohabiting with them in a conjugal relationship, having so cohabited for a period of at least one year;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a relative or dependant of the victim;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: an individual who has in law or fact custody, or is responsible for the care or support, of the victim;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: an individual who has in law or fact custody, or is responsible for the care or support, of a dependant of the victim.

Section.Text: An individual is not a victim in relation to an offence, or entitled to exercise a victim’s rights under this Act, if the individual is charged with the offence, found guilty of the offence or found not criminally responsible on account of mental disorder or unfit to stand trial in respect of the offence.
For the purpose of this Act, the criminal justice system consists of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the investigation and prosecution of offences in Canada;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the corrections process and the conditional release process in Canada; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the proceedings of courts and Review Boards, as those terms are defined in subsection 672.1(1) of the Criminal Code, in respect of accused who are found not criminally responsible on account of mental disorder or unfit to stand trial.

Section.Text: Every victim has the right, on request, to information about

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the criminal justice system and the role of victims in it;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the services and programs available to them as a victim, including restorative justice programs; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: their right to file a complaint for an infringement or denial of any of their rights under this Act.

Section.Text: Every victim has the right, on request, to information about

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the status and outcome of the investigation into the offence; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the location of proceedings in relation to the offence, when they will take place and their progress and outcome.

Section.Text: Every victim has the right, on request, to information about

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: reviews under the Corrections and Conditional Release Act relating to the offender’s conditional release and the timing and conditions of that release; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: hearings held for the purpose of making dispositions, as defined in subsection 672.1(1) of the Criminal Code, in relation to the accused, if the accused is found not criminally responsible on account of mental disorder or unfit to stand trial, and the dispositions made at those hearings.

Section.Text: Every victim has the right to have their security considered by the appropriate author- ities in the criminal justice system.
Every victim has the right to have reasonable and necessary measures taken by the appropriate authorities in the criminal justice system to protect the victim from intimidation and retaliation.
Every victim has the right to have their privacy considered by the appropriate authorities in the criminal justice system.
Every victim has the right to request that their identity be protected if they are a complainant to the offence or a witness in proceedings relating to the offence.
Every victim has the right to request testimonial aids when appearing as a witness in proceedings relating to the offence.

Every victim has the right to convey their views about decisions to be made by appropriate authorities in the criminal justice system that affect the victim’s rights under this Act and to have those views considered.
Every victim has the right to present a victim impact statement to the appropriate authorities in the criminal justice system and to have it considered.
Every victim has the right to have the court consider making a restitution order against the offender.
Every victim in whose favour a restitution order is made has the right, if they are not paid, to have the order entered as a civil court judgment that is enforceable against the offender.

Subsection.Text: This Act applies in respect of a victim of an offence in their interactions with the criminal justice system

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: while the offence is investigated or prosecuted;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: while the offender is subject to the corrections process or the conditional release process in relation to the offence; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: while the accused is, in relation to the offence, under the jurisdiction of a court or a Review Board, as those terms are defined in subsection 672.1(1) of the Criminal Code, if they are found not criminally responsible on account of mental disorder or unfit to stand trial.

Subsection.Text: For the purpose of subsection (1), if an offence is reported to the appropriate authorities in the criminal justice system, the investigation of the offence is deemed to begin at the time of the reporting.
This Act does not apply in respect of offences that are service offences, as defined in subsection 2(1) of the National Defence Act, that are investigated or proceeded with under that Act.
The rights of victims under this Act are to be exercised through the mechanisms provided by law.

A victim is entitled to exercise their rights under this Act only if they are present in Canada or they are a Canadian citizen or a permanent resident within the meaning of subsection 2(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act.

Section.Text: This Act is to be construed and applied in a manner that is reasonable in the circumstances, and in a manner that is not likely to

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: interfere with the proper administration of justice, including

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: by causing interference with police discretion or causing excessive delay in, or compromising or hindering, the investigation of any offence, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: by causing interference with prosecutorial discretion or causing excessive delay in, or compromising or hindering, the prosecution of any offence;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: interfere with ministerial discretion;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: interfere with the discretion that may be exercised by any person or body authorized to release an offender into the community;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: endanger the life or safety of any individual; or

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: cause injury to international relations or national defence or national security.

Section.MarginalNote: Interpretation of other Acts, regulations, etc.
Section.Text: To the extent that it is possible to do so, every Act of Parliament enacted — and every order, rule or regulation made under such an Act — before, on or after the day on which this Act comes into force must be construed and applied in a manner that is compatible with the rights under this Act.

Subsection.Text: If, after the application of sections 20 and 21, there is any inconsistency between any provision of this Act and any provision of any Act, order, rule or regulation referred to in section 21, the provision of this Act prevails to the extent of the inconsistency.

Subsection (1) does not apply in respect of the Canadian Bill of Rights, the Canadian Human Rights Act, the Official Languages Act, the Access to Information Act and the Privacy Act and orders, rules and regulations made under any of those Acts.

Section.Text: No adverse inference is to be drawn against a person who is charged with an offence from the fact that an individual has been identified as a victim in relation to the offence.
Nothing in this Act is to be construed so as to permit any individual to

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: enter Canada or to remain in Canada beyond the end of the period for which they are authorized to so remain;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: delay any removal proceedings or prevent the enforcement of any removal order; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: delay any extradition proceedings or prevent the extradition of any person to or from Canada.

Subsection.Text: Every victim who is of the opinion that any of their rights under this Act have been infringed or denied by a federal department, agency or body has the right to file a complaint in accordance with its complaints mechanism.

Every victim who has exhausted their recourse under the complaints mechanism and who is not satisfied with the response of the federal department, agency or body may file a complaint with any authority that has jurisdiction to review complaints in relation to that department, agency or body.
Every federal department, agency or body that is involved in the criminal justice system must have a complaints mechanism that provides for

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a review of complaints involving alleged infringements or denials of rights under this Act;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the power to make recommendations to remedy such infringements and denials; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the obligation to notify victims of the result of those reviews and of the recommendations, if any were made.

Section.Text: Every victim who is of the opinion that their rights under this Act have been infringed or denied by a provincial or territorial department, agency or body may file a complaint in accordance with the laws of the province or territory.
Nothing in this Act is to be construed as granting to, or removing from, any victim or any individual acting on behalf of a victim the status of party, intervenor or observer in any proceedings.
No cause of action or right to damages arises from an infringement or denial of a right under this Act.
No appeal lies from any decision or order solely on the grounds that a right under this Act has been infringed or denied.

Section.MarginalNote: Review of Canadian Victims Bill of Rights
Section.Text: Five years after section 2 comes into force, a committee of Parliament is to be designated or established for the purpose of reviewing the Canadian Victims Bill of Rights enacted by that section.
